contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Elijah's spirit refers to his spiritual power. Alternate translation: "twice as much of your spiritual power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: a double portion of your spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Elijah's "spirit" refers to his spiritual power. This speaks of Elisha having this spiritual power as if it were something that physically rested upon him. Alternate translation: "Elisha does have the same spiritual power that Elijah did" or "The spiritual power Elijah had is now with Elisha" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The spirit of Elijah does rest on Elisha

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "hand of Moab" refers the Moab's "control." Alternate translation: "to give them over to the control of Moab" or "to allow them to be captured by the Moabite army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to give them into the hand of Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jehoshaphat is referred to by his presence. Alternate translation: "I honor Jehoshaphat" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I honor the presence of Jehoshaphat

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh's "hand" refers to his "power." Alternate translation: "the power of Yahweh came upon Elisha" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand of Yahweh came upon Elisha

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "armor" represents ability to fight. Alternate translation: "all the men who could fight" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all who were able to put on armor

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the doorway. Alternate translation: "the doorway" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the door

contextId.occurrenceNote: The woman did not saddle the donkey, rather the servant would have saddled it for her. Alternate translation: "she had her servant saddle a donkey" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: she saddled a donkey

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that there was something in the pot that could kill them, not that there is something dead in the pot. Alternate translation: "there is something in the pot that will kill us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: there is death in the pot

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is referred to by what he said. This phrase is a metonym for Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: "Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the word of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: "sight." The king's "view" represents what he thinks about something. Alternate translation: "in the king's opinion" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in his master's view

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is referred to by his name. Alternate translation: "Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the name of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king plans to send the men to capture Elisha for him. The king does not plan to capture him himself. Alternate translation: "I may send men to capture him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I may send men and capture him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the city where Elisha is. Alternate translation: "around the city where Elisha was" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: around Elisha

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the king of Israel is referring to his army as himself. Alternate translation: "Should I order my army to kill these enemy soldiers?" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: should I kill them? Should I kill them?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king ordered his servants to prepare the food. He did not prepare the food himself. Alternate translation: "Then the king ordered his servants to prepare a lot of food for them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: So the king prepared much food for them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "the words" are a metonym for what the woman said. Alternate translation: "heard the woman tell what she and the other woman had done" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: heard the words of the woman

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "household" represents the people who live in the king's palace. Alternate translation: "tell the king and his people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: tell the king's household

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "word" represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: "just as Yahweh had said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: just as the word of Yahweh had said

contextId.occurrenceNote: This metonym refers to the amount of money that the harvests of her fields were worth while she was away. Alternate translation: "all the profit from the harvests of her fields" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all the harvests of her fields

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "you" represents Hazel but here refers to his soldiers and not to Hazael personally. Alternate translation: "You soldiers will set ... your soldiers will kill" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: You will set ... you will kill

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the men will be killed in battle. The sword was the main weapon used in battle. Alternate translation: "kill their young men in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: kill their young men with the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "house" of Ahab refers to the members of Ahab's family and his recent descendants. Ahab is Jehoram father-in-law. Alternate translation: "the same as the rest of the family of Ahab was doing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: as the house of Ahab was doing

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Judah" is a metonym for the people who live there. Alternate translation: "destroy the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: destroy Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" refers to the control of Judah, and "Judah" refers specifically to the king of Judah. Alternate translation: "the control of the king of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Judah" refers to the king of Judah. Alternate translation: "the rule of the king of Judah" or "the authority of the king of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the rule of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "house" of Ahab refers to his family. Alternate translation: "the family of Ahab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Ahab

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "blood" of the prophets and the servants refers to their deaths. Alternate translation: "I may avenge the deaths of my servants the prophets and all the servants of Yahweh" or "so that I may punish them for murdering my servants the prophets and all the servants of Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I may avenge the blood of my servants the prophets, and the blood of all the servants of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that Jezebel commanded the people to be killed. Alternate translation: "by an order from Jezebel" or "by Jezebel's command" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: by the hand of Jezebel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is used in this verse three times. Each time, the word "house" refers to the "family" of the man specified. Alternate translation: "the family of" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that Jehu sent a messenger to deliver the letters. Alternate translation: "Jehu wrote letters and sent a messenger to deliver them in Samaria" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Jehu wrote letters and sent them to Samaria

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, sitting on the king's throne means to be appointed as king. Alternate translation: "make him king in his father's place" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: set him on his father's throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jehu's "voice" refer to what he says. Alternate translation: "to what I say" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they sent people to deliver the baskets to Jehu. Alternate translation: "sent people to take them to Jehu" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: sent them to Jehu

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jehu did not kill all of these people personally, rather he commanded for them to be killed. Alternate translation: "So Jehu commanded for all ... to be killed" or "So Jehu commanded for all ... to die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: So Jehu killed all ... and his priests

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person's "heart" refers to their loyality. If a person's loyalty is "with someone," it means that they are loyal to that person. Alternate translation: "Will you be loyal to me, as I will be loyal to you? ... 'I will.'" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Is your heart with me, as my heart is with yours? ... "It is."

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "hands" of the men refer to their "control." By being stationed around the temple they were in control of the situation and it was up to them whether people were able to escape or not. Alternate translation: "If any of these men that I brought into your control escapes" or "If any of the men that are inside gets away" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: If any of the men whom I bring into your hands escapes

contextId.occurrenceNote: "in exchange for the life of the man." Here this man is referred to by his "life" to emphasize that he did not die. Alternate translation: "for the man" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: for the life of the one

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Ahab's "house" refers to his "family." Alternate translation: "the family of Ahab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Ahab

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "heart" represents "desire." Alternate translation: "all that I desired for you to do" or "all that I wanted you to do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all that was in my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sitting on the throne represents ruling as king. Alternate translation: "be the kings" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: sit on the throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "heart" refers to a person's will and desire. Alternate translation: "in everything that he did" or "with all of his will" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: with all his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the people who live in the land. Alternate translation: "people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "them" refers to Israel and "hand" refers to the power to control them. Alternate translation: "allowed Hazael the king of Aram, and Ben Hadad, his son, to repeatedly defeat the Israelites in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: gave them continually into the hand of Hazael king of Aram and into the hand of Ben Hadad son of Hazael

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" refers to the power to control them. Alternate translation: "he enabled them to be free from Aram's power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: they escaped from the hand of the Arameans

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the strength of Jehoash's army is spoken of as Jehoash's "might." Alternate translation: "the power that his army showed when they fought against the army of Amaziah king of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: his might by which he fought against Amaziah king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sat on his throne" refers to ruling as king. Alternate translation: "Jeroboam became king after him" or "Jeroboam began to rule after him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Jeroboam sat on his throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "listen" refers to obeying the warning. Alternate translation: "However, Amaziah would not obey Jehoash's warning" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: But Amaziah would not listen

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means his army restored the land up to the border. Alternate translation: "His soldiers conquered again some of the territory that had previously belonged to Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He restored the border

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the name of Israel" represents all of Israel and its inhabitants. Alternate translation: "the Israelite people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the name of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" is a metonym for power. Also, "Jehoash" is a synecdoche representing Jehoash and his army. Alternate translation: "he enabled King Jeroboam and his army to rescue them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: he saved them by the hand of Jeroboam son of Jehoash

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "Israel" represents the people of the kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: "who had caused the people of Israel to sin" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: who had caused Israel to sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sitting on the throne represents being the king. Alternate translation: "Your descendants will be the kings of Israel for four generations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Your descendants will sit on the throne of Israel to the fourth generation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "Israel" represents the people of the kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: "who had caused the people of Israel to sin" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: who had caused Israel to sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "Israel" represents the people of the kingdom of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he had caused Israel to sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Jotham built" represents Jotham making his workers build it. Alternate translation: "Jotham had his workers build the upper gate" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Jotham built the upper gate

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "nations" represents the people of other nations. Here it refers to the people of the nations who had lived in that land. Alternate translation: "the people of other nations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Aram" represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: "took back control of the city of Elath for the people of Aram" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: recovered Elath for Aram

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a metonym that represents power. Alternate translation: "from the power of the king of Aram and from the power of the king of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from the hand of the king of Aram and from the hand of the king of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name "Israel" is metonymy for the people living there. Alternate translation: "took the Israelite people to Assyria" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: carried Israel away to Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Hand" is metonymy for control, authority or power. Alternate translation: "the control of" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand of

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Sight" is metonymy for being within the attention of Yahweh so he no longer cared for them. Alternate translation: "removed them from his attention" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: removed them out of his sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: The location "Judah" is metonymy for the people that live there. Alternate translation: "the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Hand" is metonymy for control, power or authority. Alternate translation: "handed them over to those who robbed them of their property" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: gave them into the hand of those who would take the possession as spoil

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "raised arm" is metonymy for displaying power and means basically the same thing as "great power." Alternate translation: "with very great power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: with great power and a raised arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Voice" is metonymy for the message about the command of Yahweh. Alternate translation: "the command of Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the voice of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: "In the ears" is metonymy for being able to listen. Alternate translation: "because the people standing on the city wall will hear it and be afraid" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in the ears of the people who are on the wall

contextId.occurrenceNote: "my power" is metonymy for the ability of the king himself. Alternate translation: "from me" or "from the power of my army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from my power

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Hand" is metonymy for control, authority and power. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Hand" is metonymy for control, power, or authority. Alternate translation: "out from my control" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: out of my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: "My power" is metonymy for the person whose has the power. Alternate translation: "from me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from my power

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Fall by the sword" is metonymy for being killed. Alternate translation: "I will cause him to die by the sword" or "I will cause some men to kill him with a sword" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will cause him to fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Hand" is metonymy for control, authority or power. Alternate translation: "the control of the government of Assyria" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand of the king of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: "lifted up your eyes in pride" is metonymy for a haughty or arrogant facial expression. Alternate translation: "looked at very proudly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: lifted up your eyes in pride

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Ears" are metonymy for listening or hearing. Alternate translation: "because I have heard your proud words" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: because your arrogance has reached my ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Arrow" is metonymy representing all tools of warfare and destruction. Alternate translation: "nor do any fighting here" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: nor shoot an arrow here

contextId.occurrenceNote: "House" is metonymy for what was under Hezekiah's control. Alternate translation: "Give final instructions to your household and government" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Set your house in order

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Word" represents the message Yahweh revealed to Isaiah. This is a common way of speaking, an idiom. Alternate translation: "Yahweh spoke his word" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the word of Yahweh came

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Hand" is metonymy for power, authority and control. Alternate translation: "from the control of the king of Assyria" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from the hand of the king of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: Manasseh would have commanded his workers to do the building for him. Alternate translation: "he had the high places rebuilt ... he had altars built for Baal, had an Asherah pole made" or "he had his workers rebuild the high places ... he had them build altars for Baal, make an Asherah pole" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he rebuilt the high places ... he built altars for Baal, made an Asherah pole

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name is a metonym for the person. Alternate translation: "Jerusalem is where I will forever make known who I am" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: It is in Jerusalem that my name will be forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: Manasseh probably did not do the work. His servants would have done the work. Alternate translation: "that Manasseh had ordered his servants to make" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: that he had made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh putting his "name" on the temple represents him designating it as the place to worship him. Alternate translation: "where I want people to worship me forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: that I will put my name forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "nations" refers to the people who had lived in the land of Canaan before the Israelites had arrived. Alternate translation: "even more than the people whom Yahweh had destroyed as the people of Israel advanced through the land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: even more than the nations that Yahweh had destroyed before the people of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Samaria is the capital city and it represents all the people of the kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: "against the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: against Samaria

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "house" represents family. Alternate translation: "the family of Ahab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Ahab

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "shed much innocent blood" are a metonym for killing people violently. It might be best to translate this so the reader understands that other people helped Manasseh do this. Alternate translation: "Manasseh ordered his soldiers to kill many innocent people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Manasseh shed much innocent blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "eyes" represents Yahweh's thoughts or what he considered about something. Alternate translation: "He did what Yahweh considered to be right" or "He did what was right according to Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He did what was right in the eyes of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "words" represents the message of the law. Alternate translation: "had heard the laws that were written in the book" or "had heard the laws that were written in the scroll" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: had heard the words of the law

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "place" represents the people who live in Jerusalem and Judah. Alternate translation: "these people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: this place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "words" represents the message that Huldah just spoke. Alternate translation: "About the message that you heard" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: About the words that you heard

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" represents a person's inner being. Feeling sorry is spoken of as if the heart were tender. Alternate translation: "because you felt sorry" or "because you repented" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: because your heart was tender

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "will not see" represents not experiencing something. Alternate translation: "You will not experience" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Your eyes will not see

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "he" refers to Josiah. He would have commanded his workers to do these things. It is likely that Hilkiah and the priests who assisted him did these things. Alternate translation: "he had them burn them ... and carry them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He burned ... and carried

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "He" refers to Josiah. He would have commanded his workers to do these things. It is likely that Hilkiah and the priests who assisted him did these things. Alternate translation: "He had them get rid" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He got rid

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "he" refers to Josiah. He would have commanded his workers to do these things. Hilkiah and the priests who assisted him did these things. Alternate translation: "He had them bring out ... and burn it ... He had them beat it ... and throw" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He brought out ... and burned it ... He beat it ... and threw

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "He" refers to Josiah. He would have commanded his workers to do these things. Hilkiah and the priests who assisted him did these things. Alternate translation: "He had them clear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He cleared

contextId.occurrenceNote: Josiah would have commanded his workers to do these things. It is likely that Hilkiah and the priests who assisted him did these things. Alternate translation: "He commanded them to bring ... and to defile ... He had them destroy" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Josiah brought ... and defiled ... He destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "given" represents being dedicated for worship. Alternate translation: "had used to worship the sun" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: had given to the sun

contextId.occurrenceNote: Josiah would have commanded his workers to do these things. It is likely that Hilkiah and the priests who assisted him did these things. Alternate translation: "Josiah the king commanded them to destroy ... He had them smash ... had them throw" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Josiah the king destroyed ... Josiah smashed ... and threw

contextId.occurrenceNote: Manasseh and the kings of Judah probably commanded their workers to make these things. Alternate translation: "the kings of Judah had had their workers make ... Manasseh had had his workers make" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the kings of Judah had made ... Manasseh had made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Josiah would have commanded his workers to do these things. It is likely that Hilkiah and the priests who assisted him did these things. Alternate translation: "He had them ruin ... He had them break ... they filled" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The king ruined

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon would have commanded his workers to do these things. Alternate translation: "Solomon the king of Israel had had his workers build"  (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Solomon the king of Israel had built

contextId.occurrenceNote: Josiah would have commanded his workers to do these things. It is likely that Hilkiah and the priests who assisted him did these things. Alternate translation: "He had them break ... they filled" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He broke ... he filled

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name "Israel" is a metonym for "the descendants of Israel." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: ruled Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name is a metonym for the honor that people should give to the person. Alternate translation: "People should worship me there" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: My name will be there

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being put "in chains" represents being captured and imprisoned. Alternate translation: "put him in prison" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: put him in chains

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mouth" represents Yahweh's command. Alternate translation: "as Yahweh had commanded" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: at the mouth of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Blood is a metonym for innocent life, and shedding blood is a metonym for killing innocent people. Alternate translation: "innocent people whom he killed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: innocent blood that he shed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Blood is a metonym for innocent life, and shedding blood is a metonym for killing innocent people. Alternate translation: "he killed many innocent people in Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he filled Jerusalem with innocent blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jerusalem" is a metonym for the people who lived there. And, "all" is a generalization. It means all the most important people Alternate translation: "Nebuchadnezzar took all the important people away from Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: He took into exile all Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name "Jerusalem" is a metonym for the people who lived in it. Alternate translation: "came with his whole army to fight against the people of Jerusalem" or "came with his whole army to conquer Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: came with all his army against Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Judah, the name of the people group, is a metonym for the people themselves. Alternate translation: "the people of Judah went out of their land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Judah went out of its land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Giving a good place at the dining table is a metonym for honoring him. Alternate translation: "more honor than the other kings" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: a seat more honorable than that of the other kings

contextId.occurrenceNote: The act of removing Jehoiachins' prison clothes represents making him a free man. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: removed Jehoiachin's prison clothes
